item.title: Orly?
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Slight desaturation adjustment.

And the shadows would be a LOT harsher and sharper than that. Use the chair’s shadows as a reference.

Read full topic

item.title: Orly?
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:10, topic:262829”][quote author=Frell link=topic=347080.msg2673428#msg2673428 date=1234921637]

Yes shadow is cut off.
Either he is bending backwards to look at the camera or you fucked up with perspective.
Halfway agree about the light. The bright spot is a reflection of the light, but still where it seems the light would be the shadow is not.
Also, camera flash was used (I’m assuming from the other shadows in the scene) yet there’s no shadow from that.
Compositing is also, not, just using grain to make both match. There’s a LOT more to it that I think you would really benefit from. Research it. It’ll help.

You need references. And not just a picture you took. Get the size of the table and model it exactly. Get the measurements from the camera lens to the table. Write down the aperture, focal length, shutter speed, everything. It all has to match.

The measurements of the table and the distance from camera will almost completely solve the perspective problems.

I rate believability in three levels. 0, 5, or 10.
0 - Instant recognizability as fake.
5 - Looks real. But any inspection and it doesn’t.
10 - Mind fuck.

You get a 2.5, so I kinda rate in four levels now

He is bent back naturally, his head goes back just as far as his arms do, i think you know i didn’t create the model

And i usually dont have problems with the way its standing or if its leaning, but i guess that would help. Ill do another either later on tonight or tomorrow.
[/quote]

Ok. It just seems like from that angle, if he was standing straight up and looking forward, his eyes would not be looking at the camera.

So this was just a compositing test?[/quote]
Pretty much, i also have a shit camera but it might still work.

But yes its a test, ive been bored of c4d and cant think of anything to do, and composting is always something different

Im going to do another with a simple sphere to make sure everythings going alright.

And actually a few people believed me when i sent them the picture, and called me a fag for buying it

quick for shadows:

The problem is the colors are to pure without noise, and i cant really avoid it.

I might just take another picture

Read full topic

Either he is bending backwards to look at the camera or you fucked up with perspective.
Halfway agree about the light. The bright spot is a reflection of the light, but still where it seems the light would be the shadow is not.
Also, camera flash was used (I’m assuming from the other shadows in the scene) yet there’s no shadow from that.
Compositing is also, not, just using grain to make both match. There’s a LOT more to it that I think you would really benefit from. Research it. It’ll help.

You need references. And not just a picture you took. Get the size of the table and model it exactly. Get the measurements from the camera lens to the table. Write down the aperture, focal length, shutter speed, everything. It all has to match.

The measurements of the table and the distance from camera will almost completely solve the perspective problems.

I rate believability in three levels. 0, 5, or 10.
0 - Instant recognizability as fake.

So this was just a compositing test?

item.title: Orly?
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:8, topic:262829”]Yes shadow is cut off.
Either he is bending backwards to look at the camera or you fucked up with perspective.
Halfway agree about the light. The bright spot is a reflection of the light, but still where it seems the light would be the shadow is not.
Also, camera flash was used (I’m assuming from the other shadows in the scene) yet there’s no shadow from that.
Compositing is also, not, just using grain to make both match. There’s a LOT more to it that I think you would really benefit from. Research it. It’ll help.

You need references. And not just a picture you took. Get the size of the table and model it exactly. Get the measurements from the camera lens to the table. Write down the aperture, focal length, shutter speed, everything. It all has to match.

The measurements of the table and the distance from camera will almost completely solve the perspective problems.

I rate believability in three levels. 0, 5, or 10.
0 - Instant recognizability as fake.
5 - Looks real. But any inspection and it doesn’t.
10 - Mind fuck.

You get a 2.5, so I kinda rate in four levels now :D[/quote]
He is bent back naturally, his head goes back just as far as his arms do, i think you know i didn’t create the model

And i usually dont have problems with the way its standing or if its leaning, but i guess that would help. Ill do another either later on tonight or tomorrow.

item.title: Orly?
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Yes shadow is cut off.
Either he is bending backwards to look at the camera or you fucked up with perspective.
Halfway agree about the light. The bright spot is a reflection of the light, but still where it seems the light would be the shadow is not.
Also, camera flash was used (I’m assuming from the other shadows in the scene) yet there’s no shadow from that.
Compositing is also, not, just using grain to make both match. There’s a LOT more to it that I think you would really benefit from. Research it. It’ll help.

You need references. And not just a picture you took. Get the size of the table and model it exactly. Get the measurements from the camera lens to the table. Write down the aperture, focal length, shutter speed, everything. It all has to match.

The measurements of the table and the distance from camera will almost completely solve the perspective problems.

I rate believability in three levels. 0, 5, or 10.
0 - Instant recognizability as fake.
5 - Looks real. But any inspection and it doesn’t.
10 - Mind fuck.

You get a 2.5, so I kinda rate in four levels now

Read full topic
